case_name: Brijendralal Gupta and Thakur Raghubir Singh v. Jwalaprasad

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 151 of 1960 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 151 of 1960. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 23, 1959, of Madhya Pradesh High Court, Jabalpur, in First Appeal No. 78 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 23, 1959, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Jabalpur, in First Appeal No. 78 of 1959,

facts.text: First Appeal No. 78 of 1959 arose out of judgment and order dated May 12, 1959, of Election Tribunal, Raigarh, in Election Petition No. 76/1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated May 12, 1959, of the Election Tribunal, Raigarh, in Election Petition No. 76/1957.

facts.text: Polling took place on February 25, 1957, at the General Election to the Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from the Mamendragarh Double Member Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1957, polling took place at the General Election to the Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from the Mamendragarh Double Member Constituency.

facts.text: Thirteen candidates offered themselves for election in Mamendragarh Double Member Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: Thirteen candidates had offered themselves for election either for the general or the reserved seat at the said election.

facts.text: Mr. Brijendralal Gupta (appellant 1) and Thakur Raghubir Singh (appellant 2) were the Congress candidates.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Brijendralal Gupta, appellant I and Thakur Raghubir Singh, appellant 2, were the Congress candidates while respondents 1 and 7

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 7 were adopted by the Praja Socialist Party.

anchor.surface_text: while respondents 1 and 7 had been adopted by the Praja Socialist Party, respondent 4 and one Sadhuram by the Jan Sangh

facts.text: Udebhan Tiwari (respondent 5) omitted to make the declaration regarding his age in his nomination paper.

anchor.surface_text: Udebhan Tiwari, respondent 5, bad omitted to make the declaration regarding his age in his numberination paper.

facts.text: Nomination papers were scrutinized on February 1, 1957, and respondent 5's nomination paper was rejected by the returning officer due to omission of age.

anchor.surface_text: This defect was discovered at the time of the scrutiny of the numberination papers on February 1, 1957, and as a result his numberination paper was rejected

facts.text: Respondent 6 withdrew his candidature, resulting in eleven candidates contesting the election.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently respondent 6 withdrew his candidature with the result that eleven candidates took part in the companytest.

facts.text: Appellants 1 and 2 were declared duly elected to the General and Reserved seats respectively after polling and counting.

anchor.surface_text: After the polling took place and the votes secured by the companytesting candidates were companynted appellants 1 and 2 were declared duly elected

facts.text: Jwalaprasad (respondent 1) filed an election petition under s. 81 of the Act challenging the election of the appellants, including ground of improper rejection of respondent 5's nomination.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Jwalaprasad, respondent 1, filed an election petition under s. 81 of the Act challenging the election of the appellants on several grounds,

facts.text: Election Petition No. 76/1957 was tried by Election Tribunal, Raigarh.

anchor.surface_text: This election petition was made over for trial to the Election Tribunal, Raigarh.

facts.text: Election Tribunal framed 49 issues, three relating to rejection of respondent 5's nomination.

anchor.surface_text: On the companytentions raised by the parties before it the Election Tribunal framed as many as 49 issues but in the present appeal we are companycerned

facts.text: Election Tribunal held that respondent 5 did not attempt to rectify the defect, returning officer could not allow remedy at scrutiny, and error was substantial defect; dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that respondent 5 did number make any attempt to rectify the defect in the numberination paper, that the returning officer companyld number

facts.text: Respondent 1 appealed to Madhya Pradesh High Court under s. 116A.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1 then preferred an appeal against the decision of the Tribunal before the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur under s. 116A of the Act.

facts.text: High Court allowed the appeal, held respondent 5 offered to supply omission but returning officer refused, required summary enquiry, omission not substantial defect, set aside appellants' election under s.100(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has allowed the appeal it has held that respondent 5 had at the time of the scrutiny offered to supply the omission but the returning officer

facts.text: Appellants appealed to Supreme Court by special leave against High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision of the High Court that the appellants have companye to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted High Court's finding that respondent 5 attempted to rectify omission but returning officer did not allow it.

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, deal with the present appeal on the basis that respondent 5 attempted to rectify the omission but was number allowed to do so by the returning officer.

facts.text: Returning officer rejected respondent 5's nomination suo motu, holding failure to declare age not clerical or technical but substantial as necessary under Art. 173.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 116A of the Act is wide enough and is not confined to questions of law.

anchor.surface_text: but, in our opinion, it was open to the High Court to consider the correctness or the propriety of the said finding because the jurisdiction a of the High Court under s. 116A of the Act is wide enough and is not confined to questions of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of s.116A allows review of factual findings by Tribunal.

holdings.text: The omission to specify age in the nomination paper constitutes a defect under s.36(4).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the context it would be unreasonable to hold that the word defect under s. 36 4 excludes all cases of omission to specify the details prescribed by the statute in the nomination paper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meaning of 'defect' includes omission; purposive reading in context of s.33 requirements; rejects English precedents as not broadly applicable.

holdings.text: No enquiry under s.36(2)(a) is required where there is non-compliance with s.33; case falls under s.36(2)(b) and scrutiny limited to whether defect substantial under s.36(4).

anchor.surface_text: If the nomination paper of respondent 5 did not comply with the provisions of s. 33 the case fell squarely under s. 36 2 b and the only question which can arise in such a case is whether or not the defect arising from the failure to comply with the provisions of s. 33 is of a substantial character or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of s.36(2)(a) and (b); distinguishes cases of apparent qualification from formal non-compliance.

holdings.text: The failure to specify the age in the nomination paper amounts to a defect of a substantial character under s.36(4).

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the question as to whether the failure to specify the age in the nomination paper amounts to a defect of a substantial character under s. 36 4 or not. There is little doubt that the age of the candidate is as important as his identity,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Age as crucial as identity under Art.173; placed prominently in form over signature; contrast with symbols proviso under rule 5; policy of election purity.

holdings.text: Certified copy of electoral roll under s.36(7) raises rebuttable presumption only of elector status (not less than 21 years), not of qualification to stand (25 years under Art.173).

anchor.surface_text: under s. 36 7 a certified copy of the entry in the electoral roll shall be conclusive evidence of the fact that the person referred to in that entry is an elector for that constituency unless it is proved that he is subject to a disqualification

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of s.36(7), cross-referencing RPA 1950 ss.16,19; distinguishes elector from candidate qualification; legislative amendment history.

holdings.text: The rejection of respondent 5's nomination paper was proper as the defect was substantial.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, if the defect in the nomination paper of respondent 5 was not of a substantial character the High Courts decision would be right on the other hand, if the said defect is of a substantial character then the rejection of respondent 5s nomination paper would be proper

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies holdings h2,h3,h4 to facts; returning officer correctly rejected under s.36(2)(b),(4).

holdings.text: Improper rejection under s.100(1)(c) not established; election of appellants not void.

anchor.surface_text: In The Queen v. Tugwell Cockburn, C. J., held that the 9 votes whose validity was impeached had to be struck off because they had not complied with s. 32 of the Municipal Corporation Act (5 & 6 Wm. 4, c. 76) and so s. 142 could not cure their defect.

precedents.cited_proposition: total omission to supply the description required by s. 32 cannot be treated as inaccurate description and cured by s. 142
precedents.cited_holding: the 9 votes... had to be struck off because they had not complied with s. 32... total omission of description

anchor.surface_text: To the same effect is the decision in Baldwin Ellis 2. In that case the omission to state in the nomination paper the name of the parish for which the person nominated was qualified as a local government elector was held to be non-compliance with the requirements of rule 4 of the Rural District Councillors Election Order, 1896,

precedents.cited_proposition: omission to state name of parish is non-compliance not curable as inaccurate description
precedents.cited_holding: omission... was held to be non compliance... could not be cured by s.13 of the Ballot Act

precedents.citation: Rattan Anmol Singh v. Atma Ram

anchor.surface_text: In Rattan Anmol Singh v. Atma Ram 1 this Court has held that the attestation required in the case of proposers and seconders who are not able to write their names is not a technical or unsubstantial matter, and so the failure to comply with the said requirement would amount to a defect of a substantial character.

precedents.case_name: Rattan Anmol Singh v Atma Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: attestation for illiterate proposers is substantial requirement
precedents.cited_holding: attestation required... is not a technical or unsubstantial matter... defect of a substantial character

precedents.citation: Pranlal Thakorlal Munshi Indubhai Bhailabhai Amin

anchor.surface_text: In Pranlal Thakorlal Munshi Indubhai Bhailabhai Amin 1, the Election Tribunal, Baroda, has held that the omission by the candidate to mention his age in the nomination paper is a defect of a substantial character and that his nomination paper had been properly rejected on that account.

precedents.case_name: Pranlal Thakorlal Munshi v Indubhai Bhailabhai Amin
precedents.cited_proposition: omission to mention age in nomination paper is substantial defect
precedents.cited_holding: omission by the candidate to mention his age... is a defect of a substantial character

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have then referred us to certain decisions where the effect of the failure to specify the electoral roll number or other particulars has been considered, and it has been held that the failure in question amounts to a substantial defect under s. 36(4) of the Act. Vide Rup Lal Jugraj Singh 2

precedents.cited_proposition: failure to specify electoral roll number is substantial defect

precedents.citation: Brij Sundar Sharma v. Election Tribunal, Jaipur

anchor.surface_text: Vide Rup Lal Jugraj Singh 2 Brij Sundar Sharma v. Election Tribunal, Jaipur 3 Balasubrahmanyan v. Election Tribunal, Vellore 4 and Ramayan Shukla v. Rajendra Prasad Singh 5.

precedents.case_name: Brij Sundar Sharma v Election Tribunal Jaipur
precedents.cited_proposition: failure to specify particulars like electoral roll number is substantial defect

anchor.surface_text: Brij Sundar Sharma v. Election Tribunal, Jaipur 3 Balasubrahmanyan v. Election Tribunal, Vellore 4 and Ramayan Shukla v. Rajendra Prasad Singh 5. By parity of reasoning the appellants contend that the failure to mention the age is undoubtedly a substantial defect.

precedents.cited_proposition: failure to specify particulars is substantial defect

precedents.citation: Ramayan Shukla v. Rajendra Prasad Singh

anchor.surface_text: Balasubrahmanyan v. Election Tribunal, Vellore 4 and Ramayan Shukla v. Rajendra Prasad Singh 5. By parity of reasoning the appellants contend that the failure to mention the age is undoubtedly a substantial defect.

precedents.case_name: Ramayan Shukla v Rajendra Prasad Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: failure to specify particulars is substantial defect

precedents.citation: Durga Shankar Mehta v. Thakur Raghuraj Singh

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand the respondents have relied on the decision of this Court in the case of Durga Shankar Mehta v. Thakur Raghuraj Singh 6. Indeed it appears from the judgment of the High Court under appeal that in coming to its decision the High Court was influenced by certain observations made by Mukherjea, J.

precedents.case_name: Durga Shankar Mehta v Thakur Raghuraj Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: acceptance of nomination proper unless want of qualification apparent on face or objection raised and wrongly decided
precedents.cited_holding: acceptance would have been improper if the want of qualification was apparent on the electoral roll itself or on the face of the nomination paper

precedents.citation: Pratap Singh v. Shri Krishna Gupta

anchor.surface_text: The respondents have also relied upon the decision of this Court in Pratap Singh v. Shri Krishna Gupta 2. In that case this Court has no doubt observed that courts should not adopt a technical attitude in dealing with election matters and that it is the substance that must count

precedents.case_name: Pratap Singh v Shri Krishna Gupta
precedents.cited_proposition: courts should not adopt technical attitude; substance over form
precedents.cited_holding: courts should not adopt a technical attitude in dealing with election matters and that it is the substance that must count and it must take precedence over mere form

anchor.surface_text: There is another decision of this Court on which the respondents have relied. That is the case of Karnail Singh Election Tribunal, Hissar 2. It appears that in that case the nomination paper of Sher Singh had been rejected on the ground that column 8 in the nomination form was not duly filled up.

precedents.case_name: Karnail Singh v Election Tribunal Hissar
precedents.cited_proposition: omission of sub-division name in column 8 is purely technical defect
precedents.cited_holding: the defect in question was purely technical and that the Tribunal was perfectly right in holding that the nomination paper had been improperly rejected

precedents.citation: Pt. Charanjit Lal Ram Sarup v. Lahri Singh Ram Narain

anchor.surface_text: There is one more decision on which the respondents have relied. In Pt. Charanjit Lal Ram Sarup v. Lahri Singh Ram Narain 3 the Punjab High Court was dealing with a case where the nomination paper of a candidate had been rejected not only on account of the omission to state the age

precedents.case_name: Charanjit Lal Ram Sarup v Lahri Singh Ram Narain
precedents.cited_proposition: omission to state age not necessarily substantial if evidence available
precedents.cited_holding: the omission to state the age was not a defect of a substantial character (inclined view)

justification_sets.label: Section 116A, Representation of the People Act, 1951 support
Section 36(4), Representation of the People Act, 1951 support

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the question as to whether the failure to specify the age in the nomination paper amounts to a defect of a substantial character under s. 36 4 or not. There is little doubt that the age of the candidate is as important as his identity, and in requiring the candidate to specify his age the prescribed form has given a place of importance to the declaration about the candidates age. Just as the nomination paper must show the full name of the candidate and his electoral roll number, and just as the nomination paper must be duly signed by the candidate, so must it contain the declaration by the candidate about his age.

outcome.relief_summary: Omission to specify age amounts to defect of substantial character; rejection of nomination paper proper; High Court erred

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the context it would be unreasonable to hold that the word defect under s. 36 4 excludes all cases of omission to specify the details prescribed by the statute in the nomination paper.

That takes us to the question as to whether the failure to specify the age in the nomination paper amounts to a defect of a substantial character under s. 36 4 or not. There is little doubt that the age of the candidate is as important as his identity, and in requiring the candidate to specify his age the prescribed form has given a place of importance to the declaration about the candidates age. Just as the nomination paper must show the full name of the candidate and his electoral roll number, and just as the nomination paper must be duly signed by the candidate, so must it contain the declaration by the candidate about his age.

anchor.surface_text: If the nomination paper of respondent 5 did not comply with the provisions of s. 33 the case fell squarely under s. 36 2 b and the only question which can arise in such a case is whether or not the defect arising from the failure to comply with the provisions of s. 33 is of a substantial character or not.
